title: Corballis Lab
text:
Corballis Lab 2023





The Corballis lab founded by Professor Paul M. Corballis in 2011 is a research laborartory in The School of Psychology at the University of Auckland.

title: Contact Us
text:
Email: corballislabnz@gmail.com
We are located in the UoA Science Center.
The address is 23 Symonds St, Auckland, 1010. Click here for directions

title: Meet the team
text:
Paul Corballis
Lab Director


Paul summary














Tamar McCambridge
Masters Student


placeholder text








Sam Morrison
PhD Student





placeholder text





Eric Rosentreter
PhD Student


Eric is a PhD student in the field of cognitive neuroscience, with a specific focus on visual selective attention. He is a dedicated and enthusiastic researcher who is committed to advancing our understanding of how the brain processes and filters visual information. Eric’s research centers on the mechanisms of attentional control, exploring how we selectively attend to certain features in the visual environment while ignoring others. He is particularly interested in the neural underpinnings of attentional processes and how they are affected by factors such as task demands and cognitive load.








Darrilyn Li
Masters Student





placeholder text





Carley Braddock
PhD Student


placeholder text








Daniele Scanzi
PhD Student





Daniele completed his Bachelor of Science in Psychology and Communication at the University of Milan – Bicocca in 2018. He joined the University of Auckland in 2021 as an Honours student. He is now starting a PhD working with Paul Corballis, director of the Cognitive Psychophysiology Lab, and is co-advised by Christopher Erb. He is interested in investigating the neural correlates of consciousness using EEG, eye-tracking and whatever other machinery he can get his hands on. He has a second identity as a magician and his assistant is a tiny blue plunger.





Courtney Haselton
Honours Student


placeholder text








Katie Smith
PhD Student





placeholder text





Andre Botes
PhD Student


Andre is a PhD student investigating how we use value assessments affect how we make every day decisions. Andre is interested in question about how behaviour is controlled to meet our goals and what mechanisms we use to make this happen. Before starting his doctorate, Andre worked on projects using virtual reality and EEG.
